posts.name: Tio
posts.cooked:
Hi

Any suggestions on controllers for competition. We have been using the logictech ones and have had some issues with buttons and joysticks. It is not programming, more mechanical with controller.

Thank you in advance

posts.name: Peter B
posts.cooked: Our team has used Xbox Wireless controllers for the past two years, so far we have loved them over our old Logitech joysticks. Just make sure to get a relatively long usb c cable for a driver station connection

posts.name: Jim Barstow
posts.cooked:
Xbox controllers. The Logitech F310 controllers have terrible analog sticks that don’t zero well, a mode button that will really mess up your day (hint: superglue the mode button to eliminate this.).

We use Stadia controllers, which we really like, but future availability is limited and we will likely switch to either Xbox controllers or Sony Dualshock controllers in the next couple years.

posts.name: Jared
posts.cooked: Have you ever had any issues of the USB-C cable pulling out of the controller during match? That’s the only thing making me hesitate from buying ‘better’ controllers for my team.

posts.name: Jim Barstow
posts.cooked: We have had no issues with our Stadia controllers unplugging (USB-C) during matches at all.
Switch to a Hall Effect Xbox controller imo, check out GuliKit (i promise we arent sponsored i just love them)

posts.name: Peter B
posts.cooked: no connection issues at all, the port has been very snug on the controller side. We started by borrowing a team members xbox controllers for a trial run at an offseason event before making the purchase for ourselves, I would recommend doing that if you have the ability

posts.name: Peter B
posts.cooked: I haven’t heard of a team using stadia controllers, although they are relatively cheap on eBay. What do y’all like about them over other options?

correct me if im wrong but iirc one of the logitech wired controllers cost 1477 their champs run in 2015? *it might have been a first party wired xbox controller now that i think about it, been a while since i watched roboleague

posts.name: Jim Barstow
posts.cooked:
Pros:

The feel, shape, and weight of them.

The joysticks return positively to zero when you let them go, and don’t drift.

There is a few more buttons that we can use and assign to things.

The LT and RT are buttons, not axis.

We can unplug them and use them BT in the lab to walk around with the robot for testing.

Cheap and readily available (currently).

Has a command wrapper in WPILib (like Xbox and PS), because I wrote it.

Cons:

Not a lot of people using them.

After December 2024, they might not be able to be converted from Stadia to Bluetooth anymore (if Google ends the website for converting them).

Related to #2 , you have to make sure they are converted to bluetooth (1 time deal, takes only a minute or two.)

Rumble doesn’t work.

The stadia controller class in WPILib is slightly better than the xbox one, since it exposes more of the face buttons (giving you a few extra buttons to assign). Otherwise, it’s just a nice controller that you can connect over USB C

posts.name: Ian Saam
posts.cooked: We switched to a razer wolverine v2 chroma this year, and I couldn’t be happier. The extra buttons near the triggers and four paddles on the back all remap to the face buttons + start and home, so I never have to take my thumbs off the joysticks of the controller to do any actions. They are quite pricy, but if you can afford them I have 0 regrets switching this year.

posts.name: Jim Barstow
posts.cooked: If there is missing face buttons from the xbox controller class, this would be really easy to fix and issue a PR for.  Do you have more information on which buttons are missing from the wrapper?

The share button in the center of the controller is the only one that is not accessible (and having looked up what it is called, this does not seem to be on every XBox controller, likely why it is omitted from the wrapper). The stadia controller has 4 face buttons, all of which are usable. Not including the main button for either controller, as I assume that has some preconfigured hardware use cases (powering off, pairing, etc.) that make it unsuitable for mapping, though those are also missing

posts.name: Jim Barstow
posts.cooked: Thanks. When I did the stadia wrapper, I also included the Stadia button, although it would be unwise to use it for anything that needed other than a momentary press. (long pressing it over 7 seconds will turn off the controller). We use that for temporary non-match critical maintenance functions.

posts.name: system
posts.cooked: This topic was automatically closed 180 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.

suggested_topics.fancy_title: Swerve wheels spinning different directions after assigning CanCoder ID’s
suggested_topics.title: Swerve wheels spinning different directions after assigning CanCoder ID's
suggested_topics.excerpt: We solved it. Our cancoder ID’s were not aligned with our spark max id’s therefore causing the issue
